citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Four animals are in need of veterinary attention:
*Three goats were identified as holding up a limb and reluctant to put weight on the affected limb while walking. This
included two female tricolor goats (front left limb) and the male tricolor/mostly black and white billy goat (hind right limb).
The licensee has tried treating with medications that have worked in the past as this has become a frequent problem with
weather changes but they don't seem to be helping so the licensee has set up an appointment for later in the week with
the hoof trimmer. The veterinarian has not been contacted about these goats.
*The young waffalo appears thin with ribs and hip bones visually protruding. The licensee stated that he is eating well and
has been healthy. The veterinarian has not been contacted.
The facility shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries by contacting the
veterinarian to advise the vet of the these issues and follow all veterinary recommendations. Correct by 7/27/24.

The facility has obtained several new animals and has had several offspring born that have not yet been added to the
facility's acquisition records. These animals include two llamas, a zebu, 3 mini piglets, two African crested porcupines, a
coatimundi and two goats. Records of acquisition to include information about the animals and the source of the animals
are necessary to allow for legal and medical tracking of the animals. The facility shall make and keep records which fully
and correctly disclose all the required acquisition information (date of acquisition, name and address of person from whom
animal was acquired, USDA license number or drivers license number and state, and species of animal) for all animals
other than dogs and cats purchased or otherwise acquired and in their possession/under their control including any
offspring born. Correct by 8/7/24.

The following enclosures are in need of repair:
*The area between the two sides of enclosures/pastures was housing sheep and goats to allow them to eat the grass
during this inspection. Several fence panels were propped up along the sides and one had fallen to the ground. The goats
and sheep may be injured if an unsecured panel were to fall on the animals and if they climb around/under the panels.
*The African crested porcupine enclosure consists of metal wire bottom on dirt. The porcupines have dug out the dirt
leaving holes/space between the wire floor and the dirt. The animals may injure themselves trying to balance on the wires
or slip and injure their feet/legs while moving around their enclosure.
The housing facilities must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.

The enclosure/pasture housing the goats is in need of weed control. The weeds covering the enclosure range from a few
inches tall up to three plus feet tall. In the back half of the enclosure they are almost as tall as the calf hutches used as
shelter structures for the goats. The weeds make it difficult to complete the prescribed husbandry practices such as daily
observation (goats in the weeds will not be visible) and cleaning/removing excreta. In addition, pests and parasites can
proliferate in the weeds.
Premises and grounds must be kept clean and cleared to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in the
Animal Welfare Standards and to protect the health of the animals. Correct by 7/29/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Four animals are in need of veterinary attention: 
*Three goats were identified as holding up a limb and reluctant to put weight on the affected limb while walking. This 
included two female tricolor goats (front left limb) and the male tricolor/mostly black and white billy goat (hind right limb). 
The licensee has tried treating with medications that have worked in the past as this has become a frequent problem with 
weather changes but they don't seem to be helping so the licensee has set up an appointment for later in the week with 
the hoof trimmer. The veterinarian has not been contacted about these goats.  
*The young waffalo appears thin with ribs and hip bones visually protruding. The licensee stated that he is eating well and 
has been healthy. The veterinarian has not been contacted. 
The facility shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases and injuries by contacting the 
veterinarian to advise the vet of the these issues and follow all veterinary recommendations. Correct by 7/27/24. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility has obtained several new animals and has had several offspring born that have not yet been added to the 
facility's acquisition records. These animals include two llamas, a zebu, 3 mini piglets, two African crested porcupines, a 
coatimundi and two goats. Records of acquisition to include information about the animals and the source of the animals 
are necessary to allow for legal and medical tracking of the animals. The facility shall make and keep records which fully 
and correctly disclose all the required acquisition information (date of acquisition, name and address of person from whom 
animal was acquired, USDA license number or drivers license number and state, and species of animal) for all animals 
other than dogs and cats purchased or otherwise acquired and in their possession/under their control including any 
offspring born. Correct by 8/7/24. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The following enclosures are in need of repair: 
*The area between the two sides of enclosures/pastures was housing sheep and goats to allow them to eat the grass 
during this inspection. Several fence panels were propped up along the sides and one had fallen to the ground. The goats 
and sheep may be injured if an unsecured panel were to fall on the animals and if they climb around/under the panels.

*The African crested porcupine enclosure consists of metal wire bottom on dirt. The porcupines have dug out the dirt 
leaving holes/space between the wire floor and the dirt. The animals may injure themselves trying to balance on the wires 
or slip and injure their feet/legs while moving around their enclosure.  
The housing facilities must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The enclosure/pasture housing the goats is in need of weed control. The weeds covering the enclosure range from a few 
inches tall up to three plus feet tall. In the back half of the enclosure they are almost as tall as the calf hutches used as 
shelter structures for the goats. The weeds make it difficult to complete the prescribed husbandry practices such as daily 
observation (goats in the weeds will not be visible) and cleaning/removing excreta. In addition, pests and parasites can 
proliferate in the weeds.  
Premises and grounds must be kept clean and cleared to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in the 
Animal Welfare Standards and to protect the health of the animals. Correct by 7/29/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
